content: The Act may be cited as the "El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail Act". El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro was a significant route between Mexico City and Santa Fe, symbolizing cultural interaction and trade. American Indian groups, like the Pueblo Indians, had trade trails before European arrival. El Camino Real facilitated trade and migration in the borderland from 1598 to 1882, enabling exploration, colonization, and cultural exchange among American Indians, European emigrants, miners, ranchers, soldiers, and missionaries. El Camino Real played a significant role in the historic development of the borderland, promoting cultural interaction among Spaniards, Europeans, American Indians, Mexicans, and Americans. It fostered the spread of Catholicism, mining, commerce, and various ethnic and cultural traditions. The text chunk "SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION AND ADMINISTRATION." is a condensed summary of the authorization and administration section of a document. Section 5(a) of the National Trails System Act is amended to designate paragraphs for the California National Historic Trail, the Pony Express National Historic Trail, and the Selma to Montgomery National Historic Trail as paragraphs (18), (19), and (20) respectively. Additionally, a new paragraph (21) is added for El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail, a 404-mile trail from the Rio Grande near El Paso, Texas to San Juan Pueblo, New Mexico. The El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail feasibility study and environmental assessment report was dated March 1997. The trail shall be administered by the Secretary of the Interior, and no land outside federally administered areas can be acquired for the trail without the owner's consent. The Secretary of the Interior administers the El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail, and no land can be acquired for the trail without the owner's consent. Volunteer groups are encouraged to participate in trail development and maintenance, and coordination with various organizations and the government of Mexico is allowed. The El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail is administered by the Secretary of the Interior. Volunteer groups are encouraged to participate in trail development and maintenance, and coordination with organizations and the government of Mexico is allowed for the purpose of exchanging trail information, fostering preservation and educational programs, and establishing an international historic trail.
